Award.AbstractNarration:
A request is made to fund new and replacement instrumentation on the R/V Atlantic Explorer, a 168? general purpose research vessel operated by Bermuda Institute of Ocean Science (BIOS) as part of the University-National Oceanographic Laboratory System (UNOLS) research fleet.

The R/V Atlantic Explorer is a general-purpose research ship owned and operated by the
Bermuda Institute of Ocean Sciences (BIOS). BIOS is a U.S. 501 (c) 3 and 509 (a) not-for profit research and educational institution incorporated in the state of New York, and geographically located on the island of Bermuda. The mission of the ship is to support funded science research. The RV Atlantic Explorer has 157 days funded in 2012 and 150 days in 2011. All 157 days are NSF science days. With this proposal, BIOS provides technical descriptions and rationale for the acquisition of the following Oceanographic Instrumentation Equipment:

1) FERRUPS UPCS system $17,000
2) Upgrades for the shipboard IP/Data network $16,400
3) Bottom Finding Pinger $15,600
TOTAL $49,000

Broader Impacts:
The principal impact of the present proposal is under criterion two, providing infrastructure support for scientists to use the vessel and its shared-use instrumentation in support of their NSF-funded oceanographic research projects (which individually undergo separate review by the relevant research program of NSF). The acquisition, maintenance and operation of shared-use instrumentation allows NSF-funded researchers from any US university or lab access to working, calibrated instruments for their research, reducing the cost of that research, and expanding the base of potential researchers.

2012 Oceanographic Instrumentation R/V Atlantic Explorer

Final Report: OCE 1216572

             This award, in the amount of $49,000, was used to purchase the instrumentation, upgrades and equipment described below for installation on board the R/V Atlantic Explorer, a 170 ft. general purpose research vessel operated by Bermuda Institute of Ocean Science (BIOS) as part of the University-National Oceanographic Laboratory System (UNOLS) research fleet.

             The Bermuda Institute of Ocean Sciences (BIOS) is a U.S. 501 (c) 3 and 509 (a) not-for profit research and educational institution incorporated in the state of New York, and geographically located on the island of Bermuda. The mission of the ship is to support funded science research.

             With this award, BIOS acquired the following Oceanographic Instrumentation Equipment:

 1) FERRUPS UPCS system $17,000

             The FERRUPS shipboard Uninterruptible Power Conditioning System (UPCS) is uniquely designed to support nautical applications. The FERRUPS essentially performs two main functions. First, it regulates incoming power, conditioning it so that the protected equipment connected to the UPCS always receives computer-grade power. Second, the FERRUPS contains batteries to provide power during a power outage. Should a power failure occur, the FERRUPS seamlessly switches to battery power without interruption.

            The system is needed to protect sensitive NSF funded ships equipment.

 2) Upgrades for the shipboard IP/Data network $16,400

            The 3 new Dell R210 1U rack-mount servers, with the MS Server 2008 operating system, are modest yet powerful and scalable enough to meet our needs for the foreseeable future. The new servers will replace our primary network and email servers and allow us to expand our capability with a dedicated data server.

            We are also proposing to consolidate the existing IP routing and cabling with a new 48 port managed switch. We would like to centralize the equipment to better protect it and to localize the maintenance and add greater capacity.

            Software upgrades were included for the existing computers to maximize their service life.

            We feel that all users of the ship, science and crew, will benefit from these improvements as well as making the IT support more efficient during short cruise mobilizations. Having a consolidated and more efficient IT system and increased ability to customize the Ethernet configurations will make us a more attractive vessel for potential users.
